hangouts meet does a pretty good job of teaching you to use "new topic" instead of replying to the original post:
pasted image
I assume that's a one-time thing?
yup
I definitely prefer that approach to hotspots.

I really think staggering our ‚Äúhotspots‚Äù is a good idea. So the first time a user clicks in a particular area of performs a certain action they get the hotspot for that context. Usually people just dismiss all the hotspots the first time and never see them again.
I didn't even get that as I was first in, and I did create the thread (topic)

That being said I think an overlay with like a lucid 30 second explainer video example of using topics would do wonders for Onboarding. It‚Äôs amazing what any amount of words can‚Äôt do that a quick video with a human explaining something can üôÇ
( people coming into the realm are likely not involved or aware of the decision to use zulip vs another software ). Plus I can think of a few different areas where that video would be useful.
@Rishi Gupta I've been thinking we should have a hotspot of that form, probably worth adding it. Position-wise, I think we could put that content in our above-compose notification area.
It could go on the topic field of the compose box, is another place?
Instead of adding another hotspot, can we do what hangouts does here? Which seems 10x more sensible to me--tell you stuff when you're actually most ready to learn it.
yeah, I think it's just a matter of building the infrastructure for it.
agreed it's definitely better for the pop-up to come when you first click into the topic field, rather than there being a hotspot there.
I think we can reuse the hotspots infrastructure for it mostly. I assume there's a table that records how we've nagged the user for each hotspot?

And then the logic would be this for reply:

  • if user has been nagged, skip pro tip, continue as normal
  • else, pop pro tip using normal popover logic
  • set nagged flag
yeah, there's a table that keeps track of it (UserHotspot)
That's exactly what I had in mind -- by "hotspots" I mean things that we track using our "see-once UserHotspot" table; this one would just have different rendering logic than the existing ones.
@Rishi Gupta can you serialize this to an issue?

It would be nice to trigger other hotspots in some context-sensitive way, rather than on timers. Even if they're still pretty aggressive--like, wait to show the "Streams are like channels" hotspot until you hover over the left sidebar.
It'd be easy to do that sort of thing in the JS code, since that's where a timer would live.
Apart from persisting the UserHotspot row when a user has endured any particular step, I think all of this code is JS-side and would be fairly easy to clean up.

yeah, to be clear, I think what you're describing is the right way to handle teaching a lot of the basic functionality (which is all we're using the hotspots for now).

I think we also send them in too quickly; e.g. it might be nicer if we spaced them 5-30 seconds apart.

The long term vision of hotspots was to be able to use it for pushing feature discovery as well, e.g. when we launch new features, or notice that a user has never used X feature.

I'm totally in favor of the general concept here--have a discovery mechanism that teaches users features as they're most likely to learn. I just hate the current execution. I think we're on the same page for the former, and probably you and I don't totally disagree on the latter.
Well, if you're interested, I think this is definitely an area we'd like to work on in the near future. :slight_smile:

Well, if you're interested, I think this is definitely an area we'd like to work on in the near future. :)

@Rishi Gupta sir, I'd been trying to fix the issue of intro_compose, the main issue in production mode was the blueslip error caused by the changes in PR. Those can be easily fixed by simply changing the order of sending next hotspots.

@Rishi Gupta the changes in the PR #11948 are ready for review. It has passed all the tests and I have also tested it manually. Please have a look in your free time. In a nutshell:
1. You can now click on intro_compose irrespective of whether you have seen other hotspots or not.
2. The tests had to be modified as earlier only one hotspot was sent when initialized but now two of them are sent, namely 'intro_compose' and 'intro_reply'.
3. Once you have seen the hotspot intro_compose, the on-focus event will unbind itself. So next time it won't pop up again.
4. Clicking on intro_compose okay button does not call next_hotspot. It is abstracted from other hotspots. Had this been enabled, a specific bug arises which causes re-rendering of the hotspot yet to be seen but has been rendered already.
Thanks!
